5KwudBbcTwPvh1Y4590X.content:
# Medical Legal Issues & Protective Laws

## Doctor–Patient Legal Risks
- Negligence  
- Improper consent  
- Poor documentation  
- Communication failure  

---

## PCPNDT Act
Prevents sex determination and sex-selective abortion.

### Key Points
- Clinics must be registered  
- Sex disclosure is illegal  
- Records mandatory  

---

## MTP Amendment Act 2021
### Limits
- Up to 20 weeks – 1 doctor  
- 20–24 weeks – 2 doctors (special categories)  
- >24 weeks – Medical Board  

---

## POCSO Act
Protects children <18 from sexual abuse.

### Offenses
- Penetrative assault  
- Sexual assault  
- Harassment  
- Child pornography  

---

## IPC 375 & 376
Defines rape and punishment.

---

## Glossary
- **RMP** – Registered Medical Practitioner  
- **Cognizable** – arrest without warrant  
- **Non-bailable** – bail not a right
5KwudBbcTwPvh1Y4590X.title: Laws Related to Women, Pregnancy & Child Protection

5Od1K9buzvhFY2zVuxld.content:
# Abnormal Uterine Bleeding (AUB)

## Introduction
Abnormal bleeding from the uterus due to hormonal, structural, or systemic causes.

---

## Types
- **Acute AUB** – sudden heavy bleeding  
- **Chronic AUB** – abnormal patterns for ≥6 months

---

## Causes (PALM–COEIN)
### Structural (PALM)
- Polyp  
- Adenomyosis  
- Leiomyoma  
- Malignancy / Hyperplasia  

### Non-Structural (COEIN)
- Coagulopathy  
- Ovulatory disorder  
- Endometrial  
- Iatrogenic  
- Not yet classified  

---

## Symptoms
- Heavy periods  
- Irregular cycles  
- Intermenstrual bleeding  
- Anemia symptoms  

---

## Diagnosis
- CBC  
- Thyroid tests  
- Ultrasound  
- Endometrial sampling  
- Hysteroscopy  
- Coagulation profile  

---

## Treatment
### Medical
- NSAIDs  
- Tranexamic acid  
- Combined pills  
- Progestins  
- Mirena IUS  

### Surgical
- Ablation  
- Myomectomy  
- Polypectomy  
- Hysterectomy (last resort)

---

## Glossary
- **Menorrhagia** – very heavy bleeding  
- **Polyp** – overgrowth in uterus  
- **Fibroid** – benign muscle tumor
5Od1K9buzvhFY2zVuxld.title: Understanding Abnormal Uterine Bleeding (AUB)

7JD6hbtl5zOh3ckyDU4X.content:
# Anatomy of the Female Reproductive System

## External Genitalia (Vulva)
- Mons pubis  
- Labia majora  
- Labia minora  
- Clitoris  
- Vestibule  
- Hymen  

---

## Internal Organs
### Vagina
Elastic canal; lined by stratified squamous epithelium.

### Uterus
- Fundus  
- Body  
- Cervix  
Layers: Perimetrium, Myometrium, Endometrium

### Fallopian Tubes
- Infundibulum  
- Ampulla  
- Isthmus  
- Interstitial  

### Ovaries
Produce ova and hormones.

---

## Supporting Structures
- Broad ligament  
- Uterosacral ligament  
- Ovarian ligament  

---

## Nearby Organs
- Bladder  
- Ureters  
- Rectum  

---

## Glossary
- **Fornix** – space around cervix  
- **Doderlein bacilli** – protective vaginal bacteria
7JD6hbtl5zOh3ckyDU4X.title: Anatomy of the Female Reproductive System

8Q9QiFeNicwBJ72FtUWS.content:
# Diagnosis of Pregnancy (1st & 2nd Trimester)

## Early Symptoms
- Missed period  
- Nausea/vomiting  
- Breast changes  
- Frequent urination  
- Fatigue  

---

## Clinical Signs
- Chadwick’s sign  
- Goodell’s sign  
- Hegar’s sign  
- Uterine enlargement  

---

## Tests
### Hormonal
- hCG blood test  
- Urine pregnancy test  

### Imaging
- Ultrasound (GS at 5 weeks, heartbeat at 6 weeks)

---

## Second Trimester Changes
- Quickening  
- Linea nigra  
- Striae  
- Fundal height landmarks  

---

## Glossary
- **CRL** – crown-rump length  
- **Amenorrhea** – absence of periods
8Q9QiFeNicwBJ72FtUWS.title: Diagnosis of Pregnancy in the First & Second Trimester

E9Ti1Aog1rwidiI4Vs8v.content:
# Puberty and Adolescence

## Introduction
Physical, hormonal, and emotional changes between 10–19 years.

---

## Sequence of Puberty in Girls
1. Thelarche (breast development)  
2. Pubic hair  
3. Growth spurt  
4. Menarche  
5. Ovulation  

---

## Changes
### Physical:
- Breast growth  
- Hair growth  
- Height increase  
- Skin changes  

### Emotional:
- Mood swings  
- Increased curiosity  
- Social changes  

---

## Menarche
Occurs 2 years after breast budding; cycles initially irregular.

---

## Health Concerns
- Acne  
- Dysmenorrhea  
- PCOD  
- Anemia  
- Hirsutism  

---

## Contraception for Adolescents
- Condoms  
- OC pills  
- Emergency contraception  
- Counseling  

---

## Glossary
- **Menarche** – first period  
- **OC pills** – oral contraceptives
E9Ti1Aog1rwidiI4Vs8v.title: Puberty, Adolescence & Teen Sexual Health

EQuVyDmAPzYHfkYl4U67.content:
# Understanding Pelvic Pain

Pelvic pain = pain below the belly button.  
Can be **acute** or **chronic**.

---

# 1. Acute Pelvic Pain

## Before Puberty
- Blocked menstrual flow  
- Twisted ovarian cyst  
- Abdominal TB  
- Urine/intestinal infections  

## Reproductive Age

### Obstetric Causes
- Miscarriage  
- Ectopic pregnancy  
- Molar pregnancy  
- Twisted cyst  
- Hydramnios  
- Septic abortion  

### Gynecological Causes
- Painful periods (dysmenorrhoea)
- Ovulation pain  
- PID  
- Endometriosis  

### Other Causes
- Appendicitis  
- UTIs  
- Stones  

## After Menopause
- Pyometra  
- Cancer  
- Urinary retention  

---

# 2. Chronic Pelvic Pain
Pain lasting **>6 months**.

Causes:
- Endometriosis  
- Chronic PID  
- Adhesions  
- Fibroids  
- Post-sex pain  
- Stress, anxiety  
- Urinary/bowel issues  

---

# Investigations
- History  
- Pelvic exam  
- Ultrasound  
- Laparoscopy  
- Blood/urine tests  
- MRI/CT  

---

# Treatment

## Acute
- Antibiotics  
- Surgery (if ectopic, torsion)
- Painkillers  

## Chronic
- NSAIDs  
- Hormones  
- Counselling  
- Relaxation therapy  
- Surgery (rare)

---

# Glossary
- **Mittelschmerz** – Ovulation pain  
- **Ectopic** – Pregnancy outside uterus  
- **PID** – Infection of uterus/tubes  
- **Adhesions** – Internal scar tissue  
- **Pyometra** – Pus in uterus  
- **Hysterectomy** – Uterus removal
EQuVyDmAPzYHfkYl4U67.title: Understanding Pelvic Pain in Women

HgXRSdJXLFc8KozH1ZSG.content:
# Hormonal Therapy in Women

Hormonal therapy uses natural or synthetic hormones to treat menstrual, fertility, menopause, and other women’s health conditions.

---

## 1. Estrogen

### Functions
- Female development (breasts, periods)
- Strong bones
- Period regulation

### Forms
- Tablets (ethinyl estradiol)
- Creams
- Skin patches
- Implants

### Used For
- Menopause symptoms
- Birth control
- Heavy periods
- Delayed puberty

### Side Effects
- Nausea, breast pain
- Weight gain
- Higher clot & breast cancer risk

---

## 2. Progesterone & Progestogens

### Functions
- Supports pregnancy
- Regulates periods

### Uses
- Prevent miscarriage
- Treat heavy bleeding
- PCOS, endometriosis
- Birth control pills/injections

### Side Effects
- Mood changes
- Acne
- Blood clots (some types)

---

## 3. Androgens

Used in:
- Low libido  
- Fibrocystic breast disease  

**Danazol**: for endometriosis.

Side effects:
- Hair growth  
- Deep voice  
- Acne  

---

## 4. Clomiphene Citrate
Helps ovulation in:
- PCOS  
- Infertility  

Side effects:  
Hot flashes, mood swings, multiple pregnancies.

---

## 5. Letrozole
- Ovulation induction  
- Better than clomiphene for PCOS  

---

## 6. SERMs: Tamoxifen & Raloxifene
Used in:
- Breast cancer  
- Bone health in menopause  

Side effects:
- Hot flashes  
- Blood clots  

---

## 7. Mifepristone
Uses:
- Medical abortion  
- Fibroids  
- Missed abortion  

---

## 8. Anti-Androgens
Examples:  
Cyproterone, Spironolactone, Flutamide, Finasteride

Used for:  
- PCOS-related hair growth  

---

## 9. Prolactin-Lowering Drugs
Bromocriptine, Cabergoline  
Used for infertility, stopping lactation, tumors.

---

## 10. hCG
Triggers ovulation in infertility treatments.

---

## 11. FSH & LH (Gonadotropins)
Help egg development.

---

## 12. GnRH Therapy
Used in:
- Endometriosis  
- Fibroids  
- PCOS  
- IVF  

**Add-back therapy**: small estrogen/progesterone to reduce side effects.

---

## 13. OHSS
Ovaries overreact during fertility treatment.

Symptoms:
- Breathing difficulty
- Swelling
- Blood clots

---

## Glossary
- **PCOS** – Hormonal disorder with irregular periods  
- **Endometriosis** – Uterus lining outside uterus  
- **Ovulation** – Release of egg  
- **Fibroids** – Non-cancerous uterine tumors  
- **SERMs** – Estrogen blockers/modulators
HgXRSdJXLFc8KozH1ZSG.title: Hormonal Therapy in Women

KhN8F31cfz9t3kgpvsDQ.content:
# Understanding Miscarriage (Spontaneous Abortion)

## What is a Miscarriage?

A **miscarriage**, also called **spontaneous abortion**, is the loss of a pregnancy before the baby can survive outside the womb (usually before **22 weeks** or if the baby weighs less than **500 g**).

The lost baby is called an **abortus**.

Miscarriage is common — **10–20%** of pregnancies end this way, mostly in the first 3 months.

---

## Types of Miscarriage

- **Threatened Miscarriage** – Bleeding but baby alive; pregnancy may continue.
- **Inevitable Miscarriage** – Cervix opens; pregnancy cannot continue.
- **Incomplete Miscarriage** – Some parts come out, some remain inside.
- **Complete Miscarriage** – All tissues expelled.
- **Missed Miscarriage** – Baby has died but remains inside.
- **Septic Miscarriage** – Miscarriage with infection.
- **Recurrent Miscarriage** – Two or more consecutive miscarriages.

---

## Why Do Miscarriages Happen?

### Genetic Causes
- Chromosomal abnormalities (trisomy, monosomy)

### Hormonal / Metabolic Causes
- Low progesterone
- Thyroid disorders
- Diabetes

### Uterine or Cervical Causes
- Weak cervix
- Structural abnormalities
- Fibroids

### Infections
- Rubella
- CMV
- Toxoplasmosis
- Malaria

### Immune Causes
- Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APAS)

### Blood Clotting Disorders
- Factor V Leiden
- Protein C deficiency

### Medical Illnesses
- Heart disease
- Kidney disease
- Sickle cell disease

### Environmental Causes
- Smoking
- Alcohol
- X-rays
- Chemicals (lead, arsenic)

### Unknown Causes
- Up to 60% have no clear reason

---

## How Miscarriage Happens

- **Before 8 weeks** – Baby + sac come out together
- **8–14 weeks** – Baby comes out first, placenta later
- **After 14 weeks** – Like mini-labour: baby then placenta

---

## Signs & Diagnosis (Summary)

| Type | Signs | Cervix | Scan | Management |
|------|--------|---------|--------|--------------|
| Threatened | Light bleeding | Closed | Baby alive | Rest, monitoring |
| Inevitable | Bleeding + pain | Open | Pregnancy tissue visible | Removal |
| Incomplete | Heavy bleeding | Open | Retained parts inside | Medicine/surgery |
| Complete | Pain stops | Closed | Empty uterus | No further treatment |
| Missed | Brown discharge | Closed | No heartbeat | Medicine/surgery |
| Septic | Fever + foul smell | Open | Infection signs | Urgent antibiotics |

---

## Diagnosis

- Pelvic exam
- Ultrasound
- Blood tests (β-hCG)
- Infection swabs if fever present

---

## Treatment

### Threatened Miscarriage
- Rest
- Progesterone support

### Inevitable / Incomplete
- Misoprostol tablets
- Surgical evacuation

### Missed Miscarriage
- Expectant, medical, or surgical management

### Septic Miscarriage
- Strong antibiotics
- Surgical evacuation

### Rh-Negative Mothers
- **Anti-D injection** needed

---

## Recurrent Miscarriage – Workup

- Genetic tests
- Thyroid, diabetes screening
- APAS tests
- Clotting disorders
- Uterine evaluation

---

## Cervical Cerclage
Stitch placed at **14 weeks** to prevent late miscarriage in women with weak cervix. Removed at **37 weeks**.

---

## Glossary

- **Abortus** – Baby lost in miscarriage
- **Progesterone** – Pregnancy-supporting hormone
- **Cerclage** – Cervical stitch
- **Misoprostol** – Medicine to empty uterus
- **Anti-D** – Protects future pregnancies
- **Anembryonic sac** – Sac with no baby

---

## Abortion vs Miscarriage (Difference)

| Aspect | Abortion | Miscarriage |
|--------|----------|--------------|
| Definition | Intentional termination | Natural loss |
| Consent | By choice/medical | No consent |
| Medical process | Pills/procedures | Only needed if complications |
KhN8F31cfz9t3kgpvsDQ.title: Understanding Miscarriage (Spontaneous Abortion)

aweEugluXbXgOH0lHI8g.content:
## Why Is Birth Control Important?

### For Individuals
- Protects young women (<18)
- Prevents anaemia, prolapse, infections
- Helps family planning

### For Society
- Controls population growth
- Reduces pressure on resources

---

## What Is Contraception?
Using a method to prevent pregnancy.

Types:
- Temporary
- Permanent

---

# Types of Contraception

## 1. Natural Methods
- Calendar method  
- Withdrawal  
- Breastfeeding (LAM)  
- Mucus method  
- Temperature method  
- Symptothermal method  

---

## 2. Barrier Methods
- Male/Female condoms  
- Spermicides  
- Diaphragm/Cervical cap  

Pros: Prevents STDs  
Cons: Irritation, slippage

---

## 3. IUD (Intrauterine Devices)
- Copper-T  
- Hormonal IUD (Mirena)  

Pros: Long-term, reversible  
Cons: Cramps, irregular periods

---

## 4. Hormonal Methods
- Pills  
- Injections  
- Patches  
- Implants  
- Vaginal rings  
- POPs (safe in breastfeeding)

Side effects:  
Weight gain, acne, mood swings.

---

## 5. Emergency Contraception
- LNG pill  
- Ulipristal  
- Mifepristone  
- Copper-T  

Used within **5 days**.

---

## 6. Permanent Methods
- Tubectomy  
- Vasectomy  

---

## Special Indian Contraceptives
- **Antara** (3-month injection)  
- **Saheli/Chhaya** (weekly pill)  
- **Mala-N/Mala-D** (free pills)

---

## Glossary
- **IUCD** – Device in uterus  
- **Ovulation** – Egg release  
- **LAM** – Breastfeeding-based contraception  
- **Ectopic pregnancy** – Pregnancy outside uterus  
- **Progestin** – Synthetic progesterone
aweEugluXbXgOH0lHI8g.title: Birth Control and Family Planning – Temporary Methods

gMaqzkDcDU2Yu9Ppsut1.content:
# Tuberculosis of the Female Reproductive System

## Introduction
TB can infect the uterus, ovaries, tubes, etc.

---

## Spread
- From lungs (50%)
- Lymph nodes
- Kidneys/intestines  
- Blood/lymph spread  

Most affected:
- Tubes (almost all)
- Endometrium (50–60%)
- Ovaries (20–30%)
- Cervix (5–15%)
- Vulva/vagina (<1%)

---

## Pathology
- Granulomas  
- Pus collections  
- Blocked tubes  
- Asherman’s syndrome  

---

## Symptoms
- Infertility (most common)
- Irregular periods
- Pelvic pain
- Discharge
- Abdominal mass

---

## Diagnosis
- ESR  
- Mantoux  
- Ultrasound  
- Biopsy  
- PCR/NAAT  
- Laparoscopy  
- HSG (limited use)  
- Chest X-ray  

---

## Treatment

### Anti-TB Therapy (6–8 months)

**2 months:**  
- Rifampicin  
- Isoniazid  
- Pyrazinamide  
- Ethambutol  

**Next 4 months:**  
- Rifampicin + Isoniazid  

Drug-resistant TB → stronger medicines.

---

## Surgery (Rare)
- Hysterectomy  
- Oophorectomy  
- Drainage of pus

**Tuboplasty not recommended.**

---

## Fertility Outcomes
- 10% conceive after treatment  
- 50% ectopic risk  
- 20–30% miscarriage  
- 2% term pregnancy  

IVF may help if uterus not damaged.

---

## Glossary
- **Pyosalpinx** – Pus in tubes  
- **Caseation** – Cheese-like tissue  
- **FNAC** – Needle test  
- **IVF** – Test tube baby  
- **Fistula** – Abnormal connection
gMaqzkDcDU2Yu9Ppsut1.title: Female Genital Tuberculosis (FGT)
